King Edward IV of England’s daughter Elizabeth of York, the eventual wife of Henry VII learned French, had her wardrobe remade in the French style, and was trained in continental court etiquette in anticipation of a proposed marriage to the eldest son of Louis XI of France. The degree to which the princess was trained to assimilate into the French court reflected England’s status as a lesser power in the fifteenth century. See Nancy Lenz Harvey, Elizabeth of York: The Mother of Henry VIII (New York: MacMillan Publishing Co, 1973), pp. 29–30.
